description: From Yiddish קיבעצן‎ (kibetsn), cognate to German kiebitzen (“to look on”), from German Kiebitz (“lapwing”), from Middle High German gibiz (“plover”), imitative of its cry.

verbs.description: kibitz (third-person singular simple present kibitzes, present participle kibitzing, simple past and past participle kibitzed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make small talk or idle chatter.
(intransitive) To give unsolicited or unwanted advice or make unhelpful or idle comments, especially to someone playing a game.
examples: Quit kibitzing! You're giving away my hand!

entries.meaning: (intransitive, transitive) To watch a card or board game.
